Synthesis of cis-1,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropene by catalytic isomerization of trans-1,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropene over alumina catalysts Di Zhang Conceptualization Methodology Validation Formal analysis Investigation Resources Data curation Writing - original draft Writing - review & editing Visualization Project administration a b c Jianjun Zhang Conceptualization Resources Funding acquisition b c Dalin Sun Writing - review & editing a * a Department of Materials Science, Fudan University, Shanghai, 200433, China Department of Materials Science Fudan University Shanghai 200433 China Department of Materials Science, Fudan University, Shanghai, 200433, China b Zhejiang Research Institute of Chemical Industry, Hangzhou 210023, Zhejiang, China Zhejiang Research Institute of Chemical Industry Hangzhou Zhejiang 210023 China Zhejiang Research Institute of Chemical Industry, Hangzhou 210023, Zhejiang, China c State Key Laboratory of Fluorinated Greenhouse Gases Replacement and Control Treatment, Hangzhou 310023, Zhejiang, China State Key Laboratory of Fluorinated Greenhouse Gases Replacement and Control Treatment Hangzhou Zhejiang 310023 China State Key Laboratory of Fluorinated Greenhouse Gases Replacement and Control Treatment, Hangzhou 310023, Zhejiang, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Low global warming potential (GWP) refrigerant cis-1,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropene (HFO-1234ze(Z)) is a promising alternative working fluid for high-temperature heat pump designed for heat recovery in the industrial sector. As part of an effort to mass production of HFO-1234ze(Z), the isomerization of trans-1,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropene (HFO-1234ze(E)) to HFO-1234ze(Z) is performed to develop a process with high selectivity and high yield. Herein, we prepared the alumina catalysts via calcination, fluorination, and alkaline modification and tested for the trans-cis isomerization of HFO-1234ze. As a result, the alumina catalyst with appropriate weak Lewis acid sites tended to form HFO-1234ze(Z) with selectivity levels of about 97 %–99 % and no deactivation was observed following time on stream of 200 h. Proposed reaction mechanisms were described to understand the reactions over alumina surface. The present work provides a highly efficient synthetic process for industrial production of HFO-1234ze(Z). Keywords Cis-1,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropene Trans-1,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropene Isomerization Alumina Lewis acid sites Brönsted acid sites 1 Introduction As is well-known that large quantity of low-grade waste heat below 100 °C is available in many industrial processes, but it is commonly discharged into the environment in the form of exhaust gases and waste water [1]. To recover the waste heat and protect the environment, the attempts to employ heat pump technologies have been proposed and investigated [2]. High-temperature heat pumps (HTHPs) can upgrade the waste heat to the temperature of 100−150 °C and work as hot dryers and steam generators for various industrial purposes, which are beneficial to promote a decarbonised and sustainable industrial sector [3–5]. At present, the working fluids CFC-114 and HFC-245fa, which have been widely used in HTHPs, have GWP100 of 10,400 and 858, respectively. Nevertheless, with regard to the increasing restrictions imposed by the Kyoto Protocol and the F-Gas regulation, the working fluids with GWP﹥150 will be phased down in the foreseeable future [6–8]. This drives research and industry to develop alternative working fluids with very low GWP, and high energy efficiency levels. Recently, cis-1,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropene (HFO-1234ze(Z)) is selected as a valuable substitute for CFC-114 and HFC-245fa because of its extremely low GWP (GWP100﹤1) and very similar thermodynamic properties [9,10]. Due to the high critical temperature of 150.1 °C, HFO-1234ze(Z) can operate sub-critical cycles at high temperatures, which is often required in many industries. Fukuda et al. [3] suggested that HFO-1234ze(Z) was a suitable working fluid for HTHPs with condensation temperature exceeding 100 °C according to the results of thermodynamic and experimental assessment. Kondou et al. [11] showed that HFO-1234ze(Z) provided relatively high COP and practical benefits among several environment-friendly refrigerants in the heat pump type heat recovery systems. Longo et al. [12] provided the thermodynamic and the heat transfer assessment of HFO-1234ze(Z). All the above studies show that HFO-1234ze(Z) seems to be a very promising low-GWP working fluid for HTHPs. Additionally, HFO-1234ze(Z) can also be utilized as a potential solvent, propellant, and foam blowing agent, exhibiting expansive application development foreground [13–15]. However, the production of HFO-1234ze(Z) is heavily hindered by the low product selectivity. Up to now, HFO-1234ze has been industrially synthesized via F/Cl exchange of 1-chloro-3,3,3-trifluoropropene (HCFC-1233zd) [16], dehydrochlorination of 1-chloro-1,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropane (HCFC-244fa) [17,18], and dehydrofluorination of 1,1,1,3,3-pentafluoropropane (HFC-245fa) [19]. Other synthetic routes from starting materials, such as hexafluoropropylene [20], 3,3,3-trifluoroprop-1-yne [21], 1,1,1,2,3-pentafluorpropane [22], vinylidene fluoride [23], 2,3,3,3-Tetrafluoropropene [24], 1,1,1-trifluoro-2,3,3-trichloropropane [25], and 1,1,3,3,3-pentafluoropropene [26] were not suitable for industrial production due to the highly expensive starting materials or the multi-stage steps. The products of the above reactions (shown in Fig. 1 ) are known to be a mixture of both the trans- and cis-isomer of HFO-1234ze. Especially, the selectivity of HFO-1234ze(Z) is as low as 10 %–23 %, depending on the reaction condition and the catalyst. At present, most reported synthesis routes, however, only focused on producing HFO-1234ze(E), which was considered as a more useful product in some refrigerant applications. The isomerization transformation was studied as a feasible way to increase the yield of HFO-1234ze(E) [27–30]. Unfortunately, the research into the isomerization of HFO-1234ze(E) to HFO-1234ze(Z) is yet quite limited within our best knowledge. Okamoto et al. [31] recently investigated the isomerization of HFO-1234ze(E) to HFO-1234ze(Z) for the first time over metal fluorides consisting of Al, Cr, Mn, Zr, Ti or Mg. HFO-1234ze(E) with low boiling point (−19 °C) can be separated and recycled into the reactor. However, the target HFO-1234ze(Z) and by-product HFC-245fa form an azeotropic-like composition and could not be substantially separated by distillation [32]. Actually, the purity of HFO-1234ze(Z) working as fluid will affect the practical application in HTHPs. Few studies have been done about the catalytic activity sites for the trans-cis isomerization of HFO-1234ze. Meanwhile, the pathways of the by-product formation are still unknown. To develop a high selective process for the synthesis of HFO-1234ze(Z), we chose the alumina as the catalyst, because alumina was reported to be constructive in the trans-cis isomerization of alkenes, as well as the acid or basic sites on the alumina could be easily adjusted [33–36]. In this work, a series of alumina catalysts were prepared and characterized to investigate the relationship between active sites and catalytic performance for the isomerization of HFO-1234ze(E). XRD, BET, SEM/EDS, NH3-TPD, and py-IR techniques were employed to reveal the effect of calcination temperature, fluorination, and alkaline metal modification on the structure and acidity of the resultant Al2O3 catalysts. Through systematic investigation of the modified alumina, their catalytic activity was found to mainly depend on the surface Lewis acid sites. To the isomerization of HFO-1234ze(E) to HFO-1234ze(Z), the catalysts with the strong Lewis acid sites or the Brönsted acid sites tended to initiate the side reactions. Fortunately, the alumina calcinated at 1200 °C could exhibit appropriate weak Lewis acidity to obtain the highest selectivity of HFO-1234ze(Z). Our findings may provide a direction of preparation of highly selective catalysts for the isomerization of HFO-1234ze(E) to HFO-1234ze(Z). 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation AlOOH powder as the precursor of the catalyst was provided by Zhejiang Research Institute of Chemical Industry Co., China, and calcined at 500 °C, 650 °C, 800 °C, 1000 °C and 1200 °C in air for 3 h, respectively. The obtained catalysts were denoted as Al2O3-X, where X is the calcination temperature. The fluorinated Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by fluorinating a suspension of Al2O3-650 powder with aqueous hydrofluoric acid of 40 wt.% at room temperature, followed by calcination at 400 °C in N2 for 3 h. The alkali-modified Al2O3 sample was prepared by a incipient wetness impregnation method; the Al2O3-650 was impregnated by an aqueous solution of KF at room temperature, followed by drying at 110 °C for 12 h, and finally calcined at 500 °C in air for 3 h. The content of alkaline metal salt in the solution was adjusted to giving the calculated loading of 2 wt.% for alkaline metal. The reference catalysts (AlF3, Cr2O3, MgF2, CaF2 and BaF2) were purchased from Aladdin Chemical Reagent Co. (analytical grade). In addition, fluorinated Cr2O3 as a commercial catalyst was provided by Zhejiang Research Institute of Chemical Industry Co., China. Prior to catalytic reactions, all these samples were sieved to 40−60 mesh. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations Surface areas of the samples were determined by nitrogen adsorption isotherms on a Micromeretics ASAP 2020 instrument in static measurement mode (via BET equation) at 77 K. Before the measurements, the samples were degassed at 573 K for 12 h under vacuum. XRD patterns of the prepared samples were measured on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with Ni filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.540 Å). The elemental analysis was carried out on a scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi SU8010) at an accelerating voltage of 15 kV equipped with a X-ray energy spectrometer (EDS, 550i, IXRF Systems, Inc.) attachment. Temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was performed on a Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ-C (USA). A sample of 100 mg was treated under He at 400 °C for 1 h, then cooled to 50 °C and saturated with ammonia (5 % in He) for 60 min. Residuary ammonia was eliminated by flushing the sample under He at 100 °C for 30 min. The sample was heated in the He flow from 50 to 550 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1. The amount of ammonia desorbing from the sample was detected by a thermal conductivity detector. The peak area was converted to moles of gas using a calibration file created for the species of interest. Infrared spectroscopy of pyridine as probe molecule (py-IR) was performed on a Thermo scientific (Nicolet 380) spectrophotometer. Sample wafers were prepared by pressing 20−40 mg of the catalyst at 5 tons cm−2 and transferred to a sample holder made of quartz. All the samples were initially outgassed at 200 °C for 5 h. Background spectrum was recorded after the sample was cooled to room temperature. Spectra were recorded at room temperature, after admission of pyridine, adsorption at 40 °C and sequential evacuation at 150 °C and 350 °C. 2.3 Catalytic tests The isomerization of HFO-1234ze(E) was performed in a continuous plug-flow fixed-bed reactor at atmospheric pressure. The Monel 400 reactor was inserted into a cylindrical furnace equipped with a temperature programmer. A thermocouple well reaches the central portion of the catalyst. The 40−60 mesh catalyst (5 mL) was pretreated in N2 flow at 400 °C for 4 h before reaction. Gas flow rate of HFO-1234ze(E) was regulated by a mass flow controller. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of the system was 750 h−1. After reaction, the product gas was passed through a KOH solution and water to trap acid gases, then analyzed by a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a DB-724 capillary column (60 m × 0.25 mm). The HFO-1234ze(E) conversion and product selectivity were defined as follows: HFO-1234ze(E) = mol of all detectable products/mol of HFO-1234ze(E) in feed Product selectivity = mol of target product/mol of all detectable products. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Activity test for isomerization of HFO-1234ze(E) According to the thermodynamic calculations (Table S1), the isomerization of HFO-1234ze(E) to HFO-1234ze(Z) is an endothermic equilibrium process favored by increasing temperature. From these, the equilibrium conversions of the process as a function of temperature were calculated (Fig. S1), increasing gradually with the temperature. Then, a highly active catalyst was essential for the catalytic isomerization of HFO-1234ze(E) (Fig. 1). A blank experiment (without catalyst) was carried out under the same conditions, and the conversion of HFO-1234ze(E) was below 1 % up to 500 °C. Then, a series of Al-based compounds, Cr-based compounds and alkaline earth metal fluorides were test for the isomerization of HFO-1234ze(E). The conversion of HFO-1234ze(E) and the selectivity of HFO-1234ze(Z) are presented and compared in Fig. 2 . On the whole, all the catalysts gave rising to the HFO-1234ze(E) conversions at elevated reaction temperatures from 200 °C to 400 °C. Aluminum fluoride (AlF3) and fluorinated chromia (F-Cr2O3) catalysts showed high HFO-1234ze(E) conversions, up to 28 % at 400 °C, while the HFO-1234ze(E) conversions over alumina (Al2O3), chromia (Cr2O3), magnesium fluoride (MgF2), and calcium fluoride (CaF2) were much lower (21.4 %, 17.6 %, 19.9 %, 20.1 %). The barium fluoride (BaF2) catalyst was almost invalid and contributed to only 1 % of HFO-1234ze(E) conversion. From the product selectivity, the AlF3 and F-Cr2O3 catalysts exhibited lower selectivity to HFO-1234ze(Z) with increasing reaction temperature. Notably, the Al2O3, Cr2O3, MgF2 and CaF2 catalysts revealed very high selectivity to HFO-1234ze(Z) (97.1 %, 98.1 %, 96.0 %, 94.0 %) at the temperature of 400 °C, while BaF2 showed a low selectivity to HFO-1234ze(Z) (71.3 %). Generally, AlF3 [37] and F-Cr2O3 [38] are expected as strong Lewis acid catalysts, while Al2O3 [39] and Cr2O3 [40] possess relatively medium/weak Lewis acid centers. Teinz et al. [41] reported that the Lewis acidity of alkaline earth metal fluorides (MgF2, CaF2, BaF2) decreased with increasing atom number and, simultaneously, enhanced the Lewis basicity. Therefore, it was reasonably to deduce that the isomerization of HFO-1234ze(E) occur at acid sites of the catalyst, which further suggested the possibility to conciliate the selectivity to cis-trans isomerization by turning the acidity of catalyst. The Al2O3 catalyst showed both appreciable HFO-1234ze(E) conversion and selectivity toward HFO-1234ze(Z), and it exhibited the highest yields of HFO-1234ze(Z) at all reaction temperatures. Meanwhile, a variety of acid sites coexists on Al2O3 catalysts and can be adjusted. In order to gain understanding on the acid sites over the catalyst for trans-to-cis isomerization of HFO-1234ze(E), Al2O3 was selected for further experiments thereafter. A series of Al2O3-based catalysts were prepared by calcination, fluorination, and KF modification. The physical properties and the catalytic performances of these Al2O3-based catalysts in the HFO-1234ze(E) conversion, with activity, product selectivity are listed in Table 1 . The major product detected was HFO-1234ze(Z) with some by-products containing 3,3,3-trifluoroprop-1-yne (TFPY), 1,1,1,3,3-pentafluoropropane (HFC-245fa), fluoroethene (VF), and acetylene. Therefore, in addition to isomer transformation, both the dehydrofluorination reaction and the decomposition reaction presumably occurred over the the modified aluminas. With the increase of calcination temperature from 500 to 1200 °C, the surface area of Al2O3 decreased remarkably (Table 1), while a clear trend of an increase of the isomer selectivity was observed. Interestingly, the Al2O3-1200 sample with the lowest BET surface (15.3 m2 g−1) had the highest selectivity to HFO-1234ze(Z), although the activity for the conversion of HFO-1234ze(E) was slightly lower compared to the other calcinated aluminas. Since, the degree of dehydroxylation of transition alumina enhanced with the temperature [42,43], it should be reasonable that the dehydroxylation degree had an intimately relationship with the selectivity of cis-trans isomerization. For F-Al2O3-400 prepared by fluorination of Al2O3, the highest conversion of HFO-1234ze(E) was reached to 22.8 %, but the isomer selectivity was the lowest (79.5 %). According to the significantly increased by-product TFPY, it could conclude that the fluorination of catalyst promotes the occurrence of dehydrofluorination reaction. Besides, due to the formation of hydrogen fluoride, the formation of HFC-245fa was also promoted. For KF-Al2O3-500 catalyst, the addition of KF was favorable to increase the isomer selectivity of Al2O3, moreover, the impact of KF on the catalytic activity was almost negligible compared with the Al2O3-500 sample. The main by-product over the KF modified alumina catalyst was acetylene, which was consistent with the unmodified Al2O3-500 catalyst. Correspondingly, other by-products, such as TFPY and HFC-245fa, were effectively eliminated. 3.2 Characterization of fresh and spent catalysts To gain insight into the relationship between catalytic behavior and the structure of catalyst in the HFO-1234ze(E) isomerization reaction, the fresh and spent catalysts were characterized. Fig. 3 (a) shows the XRD patterns of various Al2O3-based catalysts before the reaction. For the Al2O3-500, Al2O3-650 and Al2O3-800 catalysts, the diffraction peaks of 45.7° and 66.9° corresponded to γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS 10-0425). When the sample was calcined at 1000 °C, the γ-Al2O3 was converted to the θ-Al2O3 (JCPDS 04-0877). The phase transformation of alumina was in agreement with the former studies [44,45]. When calcined at 1200 °C, α-Al2O3 was the dominant phase (JCPDS 42-1468), but there was still some of the θ phase remained. Besides, the BET surface area (15.3 m2 g−1) of the Al2O3-1200 sample was larger than that of pure α-Al2O3 (usually < 5 m2 g−1), further confirming the existence of the residual θ-Al2O3. In Fig. 3(a), for KF-Al2O3-500, no obvious distinction diffraction of KF was noticed, indicating the uniform dispersion of KF. For F-Al2O3-400, the diffraction peaks at 25.1, 42.3, 51.5 and 58.1° were assigned to α-AlF3 phase (JCPDS 44-231) [46], which indicated that Al2O3 was completely converted to AlF3 after HF fluorination treatment. After the reaction, the diffraction peaks assigned to AlF3 phase (Fig. 3(b)) were observed in the calcinated Al2O3-500, Al2O3-650, Al2O3-800, and Al2O3-1000 samples, although the Al2O3 peaks were still predominated, confirming that these samples were partly fluorinated during the reactions. Similar phenomenon was observed on the spent KF-Al2O3-500, though the intensity was much weaker. It was noteworthy that the XRD patterns of fresh and spent Al2O3-1200 were almost identical. No diffraction peak of fluorides was observed, suggesting that the fluorination of Al2O3-1200 did not occur during the reaction. As reported, the OH− on the surface of Al2O3 was substituted by F− during the degradation of the haloalkanes [47–49]. According to the formation of by-products VF and acetylene, we speculate that the adsorption of HFO-1234ze(E) on the surface hydroxyls of Al2O3 generated further decomposition reactions, which triggered the fluorination of Al2O3. Dehydroxylation of alumina could be achieved under the high calcination temperature [42,43,50]. Consequently, the highest calcination temperature (1200 °C) for Al2O3 led to the lowest activity of HFO-1234ze(E) decomposition. On the other hand, the hydroxyls over alumina can be fluorinated by HF during the synthesis of F-Al2O3-400. Therefore, little VF and acetylene were observed after reacting for 2 h when using F-Al2O3-400 as the catalyst. The EDS results for fresh and spent catalysts are listed in Table 2 . The F content was enhanced in the spent Al2O3-X catalysts, but it increased more remarkably in the low temperature (500 °C) calcinated samples. The content of F increased slightly after reaction over the Al2O3-1200 catalyst. These results were consistent with the XRD patterns. Compared with the spent Al2O3-500 catalyst, the content of F had less increase after reaction over the KF modified Al2O3. It was reported that the fluorination of MgO could be delayed if alkali metal species exist on the catalyst [51]. The EDS results confirmed that the addition of KF somehow suppressed the transformation of Al2O3 into fluoride. On the other hand, from EDS results, the C content on the surface of the spent Al2O3-500, KF-Al2O3-500, and F-Al2O3-400 catalysts increased remarkably after reaction, indicating severe coke formation on the catalysts. There were no obvious changes in the spent Al2O3-1200 as well as coke. In the presence of fluoroalkenes, coke deposition or polymerization of the fluoroalkenes are commonly observed on various catalyst systems after reaction, especially for the strong Lewis acid catalysts [37]. Therefore, It is convincing to deduce that the formation of carbon deposition in the cis-trans isomerization reaction is related to the acidity of catalyst. 3.3 The acid properties of catalysts To further investigate the determining factors of catalytic performance, surface acidic properties of the fresh Al2O3-based catalysts were characterized by the NH3-TPD analysis, as well as FTIR spectroscopy of pyridine adsorption. The NH3-TPD profiles are shown in Fig. 4 . The broad peaks of NH3 desorption around 116, 270, and 387 °C could be ascribed to the acid sites with weak, moderate and strong strength, respectively. As shown in Table 3 , the total acidity amount of Al2O3 was gradually reduced with the increase of calcination temperature. The fluorination of Al2O3 led to a remarkable increase in the number of acid sites with strong strength, which could break the CF bond and promote the dehydrofluorination of HFO-1234ze(E) [52]. Thus, much more products of dehydrofluorination reaction were found over the F-Al2O3-400. In contrast, the addition of 2 % KF to Al2O3 could significantly decreased the peak area in the high-temperature region. As a result, little TFPY or HFC-245fa formed as by-products over the KF-Al2O3-500. The catalytic activity had a strong relationship to the total acid amount of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 5 , a linear relation existed between the catalyst activity and total acid amount of the calcinated Al2O3 catalysts, that is, the catalyst with higher surface acidity was less active than that with lower surface acidity. The elimination of acid sites through the addition of alkali metal compound unexpectedly increased the catalytic activity, indicating that not all the surface acid sites participated in the isomerization reaction. The fluorinated Al2O3 had a similar amount of acid sites to Al2O3-500, but exhibited higher dehydrofluorination activity, as seen in Table 1. Then, it could deduce that the strong acid sites in the catalyst appear to have very limited contribution in the cis-trans isomerization. The nature of the surface acidity of the Al2O3-based catalysts were further determined by py-IR. Fig. 6 shows FTIR spectra of adsorbed pyridine after 150 °C and 350 °C evacuation on the catalysts. The presence of Lewis acid sites at 1455 and 1623 cm−1, Brönsted acid sites at 1546 and 1636 cm−1, and H-bond donor sites at 1445 cm−1 on the catalysts surface were observed in Fig. 6(a), (b). The band at 1490 cm−1 is assigned to the combination of Lewis and Brönsted acid sites [53,54]. Concentrations of Lewis acid sites (unsaturated Al3+ sites), Brönsted acid sites (surfaceOH groups and/or coordinated H2O molecules), and H-bond donor sites (mostly isolated surfaceOH groups), decreased simultaneously with the increase of calcination temperature, which were in accordance with the literature reported [39,55]. For the sample of F-Al2O3-400, the intensity of the bands at 1453 and 1623 cm−1 were increased as a result of the increasing concentration of Lewis acid centers due to fluorination [56]. Furthermore, surface species that from Brönsted acid centers on the fluorinated sample are easily removed by evacuation at 150 °C [53]. Thus, there was a large reduction in the intensity of 1490 and 1546 cm−1 peaks. The addition of KF resulted in the reduction in the intensity of 1455 and 1490 cm−1 peaks but 1546 and 1636 cm−1 peaks almost unchanged when evacuation at 350 °C. We thus speculate that the influence of alkaline modification is mainly on the Lewis acid sites. The yields of VF and acetylene over various Al2O3-based catalysts firmly validated that the Brönsted acid centers were closely related to the decomposition of HFO-1234ze(E) and the formation of C2 compounds. Fig. 7 (a), (b) show the changes of conversion of HFO-1234ze(E) and selectivity of HFO-1234ze(Z) during the reaction process. For Al2O3-500, KF-Al2O3-500, the conversion decreased rapidly during the first 60 min especially for Al2O3-500, then the conversion maintained at about 20 %. Obviously, this alternation of reactivity corresponds to the change of catalyst surface acidity and severely deposition of carbonaceous material. Refer to the above catalysts, the main by-products were VF and acetylene (Table 1), which was due to the high amount of Brönsted acid sites. Moreover, the color of spent KF-Al2O3-500 and Al2O3-500 catalysts was dark grey or completely black after reaction, indicating strong coke formation due to the identical reason. For F-Al2O3-400, the conversion also decreased rapidly during the first 60 min, and then maintained at nearly 23 %. As mentioned above, F-Al2O3-400 had relatively small amount of Brönsted acid sites but large amount of strong Lewis acid sites. The carbon deposition was serious due to the strong Lewis acid sites, which are identified as active sites for coke deposition or polymerization of hydrofluoroolefins [37]. The reduction of surface acidity caused by the carbon deposition probably resulted in the rapid decline of HFO-1234ze(E) conversion and an increase of HFO-1234ze(Z) selectivity with increasing time-on-stream. Inversely, Al2O3-1200 catalyst with the lowest surface acidity (including Brönsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites) immediately catalyzed the isomerization, and held the highest selectivity of HFO-1234ze(Z). As a results, it could concluded that weak Lewis acid sites in the Al2O3-based catalysts were enough to catalyze the isomerization of HFO-1234ze(E) to HFO-1234ze(Z). Then, the lifetime of Al2O3-1200 was evaluated. As shown in Fig. 8 , the average conversion of HFO-1234ze(E) and selectivity of HFO-1234ze(Z) were well maintained at 19.2 % and 97.3 %–99.7 % within 200 h, respectively, which indicating the excellent stability and high selectivity of the catalyst. 3.4 Reaction mechanism To understand the reactions over the alumina surface, the process of isomerization of CF3CH = CHF is described in Scheme 1 . Cis-trans interconversion of olefins requires untying of a π-bond and probably proceeds by a conventional carbonium ion mechanism [57–59]. The ideal interaction could be proposed to occur at the surface of alumina, whose chemistry is dominated by the Lewis acidity of the coordinatively unsaturated Al3+ ions [60]. The electron-withdrawing interactions between the CC double bond and the electron-accepting centers are likely to form a π-allyl complex of HFO-1234ze(E). Similar interaction of propene with Al2O3 was ascertained by the characterization of the surface intermediates using 13C solid-state NMR spectroscopy [61]. It is possible that the formation of the secondary allyl carbonium ion occurs during the formation of the π-complex. The elimination of a proton from the carbonium ion proceeds through the torsional isomerization to a cis-complex. Matsugi et al. [62] mentioned that the energy gap between the singlet state and the transition state for the trans-cis isomerization of HFO-1234ze was only -2.9 kJ mol−1,which was low enough for the isomerizations to occur on the weak Lewis acid sites of Al2O3. Strong Lewis acids are known to activate CF bonds, which is the initial step of a dehydrofluorination reaction [41]. The fluorination of Al2O3 gave rise to a remarkable increase in the strong acid sites. As a consequence, CF3CCH was obtained through the dehydrofluorination of HFO-1234ze(E) over the F-Al2O3-400 catalyst (Table 1). Meanwhile, CF3CH2CHF2 was observed accompanied by the formation of CF3CCH and HF, probably due to the hydrogen fluoride addition reaction between the HFO-1234ze and the HF. γ-Al2O3 is known as a good catalyst for skeletal n-butylene isomerization to isobutylene due to its Brönsted acidity, sufficient to protonate n-butylene, following by the formation of carbenium ions [63]. It is reasonable to assume that the alumina oxide possessed Brönsted acid sites are sufficiently strong to protonate the adsorbed HFO-1234ze(E), and finally lead to the decomposition reaction. More recently, the reaction pathways of HFO-1234ze(E) addition with hydrogen radicals were calculated by density function theory method [64]. Amounts of heat is released in the process of hydrogen addition reaction, and the generated tetrafluoropropyl radicals may further decompose to CH2CHF, CHCH, HF, and CF3 radicals. Moreover, both the strong Lewis acid sites and Brönsted acid sites can cause the formation of coke during the reaction. 4 Conclusions A high selectivity and high yield synthetic process for HFO-1234ze(Z) was achieved through isomerization of HFO-1234ze(E) over alumina catalysts. The optimized catalyst Al2O3-1200 enabled 99.7 % selectivity for HFO-1234ze(Z), and no noticeable deactivation was detected within 200 h, which were important for industrial application. Through systematical investigation of calcinated, fluorinated, and alkaline modified alumina, it demonstrated that weak Lewis acid sites over the aluminas were the active sites for the trans-to-cis isomerization of HFO-1234ze(E) for the first time. The mechanism of the isomer interconversion was also elucidated. While, for strong Lewis acid sites and the Brönsted acid sites, they could cause the dehydrofluorination and the decomposition of HFO-1234ze(E), respectively, leading to low product selectivity. As a result, Al2O3-1200 with weak Lewis acidity, as well as the least amount of strong Lewis acid sites or Brönsted acid sites, exhibits the highest isomer selectivity. These results are useful in the design of high efficiency catalyst for isomerization of HFO-1234ze(E) to HFO-1234ze(Z), and may be extended to other fluoroalkene isomerization reactions in future. coredata.dc:description: Low global warming potential (GWP) refrigerant cis-1,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropene (HFO-1234ze(Z)) is a promising alternative working fluid for high-temperature heat pump designed for heat recovery in the industrial sector. As part of an effort to mass production of HFO-1234ze(Z), the isomerization of trans-1,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropene (HFO-1234ze(E)) to HFO-1234ze(Z) is performed to develop a process with high selectivity and high yield. Herein, we prepared the alumina catalysts via calcination, fluorination, and alkaline modification and tested for the trans-cis isomerization of HFO-1234ze. As a result, the alumina catalyst with appropriate weak Lewis acid sites tended to form HFO-1234ze(Z) with selectivity levels of about 97 %–99 % and no deactivation was observed following time on stream of 200 h. Proposed reaction mechanisms were described to understand the reactions over alumina surface. The present work provides a highly efficient synthetic process for industrial production of HFO-1234ze(Z).
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of cis-1,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropene by catalytic isomerization of trans-1,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropene over alumina catalysts
